selection_criteria.relevance: Direct relevance to short-lived credentials, token security, workload identity, and compromise mitigation

top_10_papers.title: A Multi-Cloud Framework for Zero-Trust Workload Authentication
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Presents WIF with OIDC that replaces static secrets with ephemeral, cryptographically verifiable tokens, allowing workloads to authenticate without persistent private keys and mitigating credential theft. Addresses lack of robust automated rotation and revocation mechanisms.

top_10_papers.title: Establishing Workload Identity for Zero Trust CI/CD: From Secrets to SPIFFE-Based Authentication
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Introduces SPIFFE as runtime-issued, platform-neutral identity model for non-human actors. Demonstrates shift from static credentials to OIDC federation. SPIFFE identities support policy alignment, workload attestation, and mutual authentication.

top_10_papers.title: Decoupling Identity from Access: Credential Broker Patterns for Secure CI/CD
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Introduces credential broker: a policy-aware, runtime mediator that decouples identity from access in CI/CD pipelines. Part of three-part series on Zero Trust CI/CD and dynamic Workload Identity enforcement.

top_10_papers.title: Identity Control Plane: The Unifying Layer for Zero Trust Infrastructure
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Introduces Identity Control Plane (ICP), an architectural framework for enforcing identity-aware Zero Trust access across human users, workloads, and automation systems. Integrates SPIFFE-based workload identity with OIDC/SAML user identity.

top_10_papers.title: Building a Robust OAuth Token Based API Security: A High Level Overview
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Covers managing token lifecycle, automating key rotation, reducing token exposure, and ensuring atomic consistency. Explores best practices for token lifecycle management, scope definition, expiration policies, and revocation mechanisms.

top_10_papers.title: Identity Management for Agentic AI: The New Frontier of Authorization, Authentication, and Security for an AI Agent World
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Addresses how agents are designed for high-velocity, autonomous, cross-domain operation, making them uniquely dangerous if compromised. An agent wields delegated authority of a human but operates with speed and scale of a machine, creating vastly amplified blast radius for potential breach.

top_10_papers.title: Agentic AI Security: Threats, Defenses, Evaluation, and Open Challenges
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Documents EchoLeak exploit against Microsoft Copilot where infected email messages with engineered prompts could trigger Copilot to exfiltrate sensitive data automatically. Reveals cascade-based threats can compromise networks of LLM agents with alarming speed and stealth.

top_10_papers.title: A Novel Zero-Trust Identity Framework for Agentic AI: Decentralized Authentication and Fine-Grained Access Control
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Argues traditional IAM systems (OAuth, OIDC, SAML) are inadequate for dynamic, interdependent, ephemeral nature of AI agents. Proposes framework built on rich, verifiable Agent Identities using DIDs and VCs to encapsulate agent capabilities, provenance, and security posture.

top_10_papers.title: Detecting Malicious Entra OAuth Apps with LLM-Based Permission Risk Scoring
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Presents unified detection framework that constructs complete corpus of Microsoft Graph permissions, generates consistent LLM-based risk scores, and integrates them into real-time detection engine to identify malicious OAuth consent activity.

top_10_papers.title: Detecting Hard-Coded Credentials in Software Repositories via LLMs
top_10_papers.publication_status: Accepted to ACM Digital Threats: Research and Practice (DTRAP)
top_10_papers.abstract_summary: Addresses how developers frequently hard-code credentials (passwords, secrets, private keys, tokens) creating attack surfaces for backdoor attacks. Leverages context-dependent LLMs like GPT to capture contextual dependencies and reduce false positives in credential detection.

key_findings.ephemeral_credentials: Multiple papers (2510.16067, 2504.14760, 2510.25819) emphasize shift from static, long-lived credentials to ephemeral, runtime-issued tokens with short TTL to minimize compromise impact.
key_findings.workload_identity_frameworks: SPIFFE/SPIRE emerged as leading framework for workload identity with runtime attestation and temporary credential issuance (2504.14760, 2504.17759).
key_findings.credential_broker_pattern: Decoupling identity from access through credential brokers provides policy-aware runtime mediation and dynamic credential issuance (2504.14761).
key_findings.oauth_token_lifecycle: Best practices include automated key rotation, short expiration policies, and robust revocation mechanisms (2507.16870, 2512.15781).
key_findings.agent_compromise_risks: AI agents create amplified blast radius when compromised due to delegated authority operating at machine speed and scale (2510.25819, 2510.23883).
key_findings.zero_trust_architecture: Identity Control Plane integrates SPIFFE workload identity, OIDC/SAML user identity, and scoped automation tokens for unified Zero Trust (2504.17759).
key_findings.detection_mechanisms: LLM-based approaches effective for detecting hard-coded credentials and malicious OAuth apps (2506.13090, 2512.15781).
key_findings.proof_of_possession: DPoP (Demonstrating Proof of Possession) cryptographically binds tokens to client keys, preventing token theft even with short TTL (industry research).

research_gaps.limited_dpop_research: While DPoP (RFC 9449) is critical for proof-of-possession, limited recent academic research found on ArXiv - mostly IETF RFCs and industry implementation guides.
research_gaps.token_binding_deprecation: HTTP Token Binding largely deprecated; research shifted to DPoP and other sender-constraint mechanisms.
research_gaps.empirical_studies: Limited empirical studies on optimal token TTL values for different workload types and threat models.
research_gaps.agent_specific_ttl: Few papers address optimal credential TTL specifically for AI agents vs. traditional workloads.

institution_analysis.note: ArXiv papers don't always clearly indicate author institutions in abstracts. US institution preference applied where identifiable from author affiliations.
